frontmatter.title: LeetCode 103. Binary Tree Zigzag Level Order Traversal
LeetCode 236. Lowest Common Ancestor of a Binary Tree

previous.body:
This is the last month of my goal toward 150 problems done by 2025. I'll have to pick up more than a few problems this weekend. I have 56 problems remaining.

___

# Solution
```python
from collections import deque

# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, x):
#         self.val = x
#         self.left = None
#         self.right = None

class Solution:
    def lowestCommonAncestor(self, root: 'TreeNode', p: 'TreeNode', q: 'TreeNode') -> 'TreeNode':
        if root in (None, p, q): return root
        left, right = [self.lowestCommonAncestor(kid, p, q) for kid in (root.left, root.right)]
        return root if left and right else left or right
            

```
Time complexity is O(n) = n and space complexity is O(h) where the height is h. Best case the height is log(n) as a balanced tree and worst case is n as a skewed tree.

next.body:
Here are two solutions. One is recursive and the other iterative.
The iterative solution is better as it can handle larger inputs.

___

# Solution
Recursive
```python
from collections import deque
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class BSTIterator:

    def __init__(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]):
        self.nodes = deque([])

        def traverse(node):
            if not node:
                return
            
            traverse(node.left)
            self.nodes.append(node.val)
            traverse(node.right)
        
        traverse(root)
        

    def next(self) -> int:
        return self.nodes.popleft()

    def hasNext(self) -> bool:
        return len(self.nodes) > 0


# Your BSTIterator object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = BSTIterator(root)
# param_1 = obj.next()
# param_2 = obj.hasNext()
```
Time complexity is O(n) = n and space complexity is O(h).

iterative
```python
from collections import deque
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class BSTIterator:

    def __init__(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]):
        self.nodes = []
        self.pushAll(root)      

    def next(self) -> int:
        node = self.nodes.pop()
        self.pushAll(node.right)
        return node.val

    def hasNext(self) -> bool:
        return len(self.nodes) > 0
    
    def pushAll(self, node):
        while node:
            self.nodes.append(node)
            node = node.left



# Your BSTIterator object will be instantiated and called as such:
# obj = BSTIterator(root)
# param_1 = obj.next()
# param_2 = obj.hasNext()
```

frontmatter.title: LeetCode 103. Binary Tree Zigzag Level Order Traversal

post.body:
I am glad I was able to make a solution from my own intuition.

___

# Solution
```python
from collections import deque
# Definition for a binary tree node.
# class TreeNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, left=None, right=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.left = left
#         self.right = right
class Solution:
    def zigzagLevelOrder(self, root: Optional[TreeNode]) -> List[List[int]]:
        nodes = deque([root] if root else [])
        rightToLeft = False

        result = []
        while nodes:
            level = []
            children = deque([])
            for i in range(len(nodes)):
                if rightToLeft:
                    node = nodes.pop()
                    node.right and children.appendleft(node.right)
                    node.left and children.appendleft(node.left)
                else:
                    node = nodes.popleft()
                    node.left and children.append(node.left)
                    node.right and children.append(node.right)
                level.append(node.val)
            result.append(level)
            if rightToLeft:
                nodes += children
            else:
                nodes = children + nodes
            rightToLeft = not rightToLeft
        return result
```
Time complexity is O(n) = n and space complexity is O(n).
